I bought a gel callus remover but that requires you to slather your feet every day for a week, and being the lazy bum that I am I did it for two nights and promptly forgot to keep going. This microplane is awesome however! Whenever I feel a buildup of dead skin I take this out and start shaving it away, feeling instant gratification at all the dead skin sloughing away. I use it every 3 to 4 weeks, and it doesn't get rid of the calluses 100%, but enough of it that I'm satisfied.

  94. I live in the south and wear sandals about 300 days a year. My heels really take a beating. They are dry and sometimes crack in the winter. When I go for a pedicure, they take the cheese grater out. Yucky and painful. All the salons in the region have started to up charge $5 for callus removal. I thought for the price, I'd rather take matters into my own hands and try to get them under control for myself. I gave it one week; only a minute or two per foot, every other day, for one week (M,W,F,Su). I moisturized every day (used Honest Company Healing Balm). By the end of the week, my cakey callouses were all but gone and my feet were smooth. I've maintained with only a minute or two per week on each foot. Last week was the true test; I went for a pedi and they didn't say a thing about callous removal, and only used a pumice stone on the little areas they found. Yay, me! I agree with other reviewers; the directions clearly state that this should be used on DRY feet. The salons allow you to soak for 20-30 minute total before they get to the callous removal portion. No wonder big chunks were coming off! I used to waddle out of the salon and my feet would be in pain for days. This is definitely the way to go - take your time (like I did) and save yourself the pain and money.

  174. I love to go barefoot, even outside, and I live in AZ (super dry). I also love sandals more than socks and closed shoes. The result? My dermatologist took one look and said, \\"You've got Arizona heels. We all get them.\\" Nice. She said she could give me a prescription for a smelly urea lotion (ick). I declined.<br /><br />But now I have my own solution. Every review that says this thing is sharp and effective is right on. It's awesome. I've spared you the \\"before and after\\" picks of my tootsies, but I did include one of the respectable mountain of DNA that this thing got off my feet today (first use). Yikes. My feet feel sooo much better and look better than they have in years.<br /><br />Couple of tips I have learned and agree with:<br /><br />1. Do NOT get carried away with the ease of using this, especially the first time. You've read the warnings on other reviews, and I can totally see how this could happen. When the Ped Eggs first came out, I got overly excited about how great my skin was starting to look and took off too much. Just take off about half as much as you really want to and you should be fine. Then, see how your feet react. You can always do more later.<br />2. This helps with number 1 above; when you are filing, it creates a lot of dust on your feet, so it can LOOK like you need to do more. I have found that if you stop, rinse your feet off, then take another look, you will see you probably took off more than you thought. The dust can be misleading.<br />3. It seems to be a smoother result if you only go one way with this. Think of it as kind of like \\"going with the grain\\" of wood. The skin on your feet definitely has a grain. If you \\"saw\\" back and forth, you will get a rougher result.<br /><br />As for the tool itself, the blade is made in the U.S. and the handle is sturdy, kind of rubberized for a great grip. Quality tool.<br /><br />I'm really happy I read the great reviews with the tips and tricks. My feet are very grateful!great grip. Quality tool.<br /><br />I'm really happy I read the great reviews with the tips and tricks. My feet are very grateful!

  276. I do a lot of walking and running. so much so that my heels were getting a protruding callus on the edges, which caused some discomfort while walking. The Microplane Foot Rasp is the perfect tool to quickly get rid of the excessive buid-up of dead skin (hyperkeratosis). I was amazed at the amount of dead skin that was piling up on the floor when I first started using this.<br /><br />If you're used to using other callus-removal tools and use the same amount of pressure, for the same amount of time, you could easily do some damage to your heels before you know it. Be patient. Read the manual. Keep in mind that the company that makes this also makes kitchen and woodworking tools! There are other tools, such as the [[ASIN:B001JYJLMY Artemis Woman Heel Smoother pedicure appliance]], which will stop when too much pressure is placed on the skin, preventing over-exfoliating, which can damage the skin. Not so with the Microplane. If you have heavily callused heels, don't attempt to remove the entire callus one session, which could easily be done in a matter of minutes.<br /><br />Bottom line is this is a great product, but don't get carried away and overdo it on the first day.

It suggests using it on dry feet but I do both damp and dry without any issues. To get my stubborn heel calluses off I had to use it every night for about five minutes or so. After five nights of this routine (plus some foot cream), I can say my feet are GORGEOUS. No calluses, no scratchy parts, no dry patches - just awesome, pink feet. I'm at the point where I only use this every few days to briefly maintain my feet and keep them from getting calluses (I wear flip flops and sandals all day so its necessary). Honestly, this product is amazing. You have to be diligent in the beginning to remove the calluses and do it slowly (you can't hack away into the skin like crazy or you're left with sore, raw feet). Go slow and I promise you, your feet will be awesome in a few days of constant effort. Seriously, five or ten minutes a night and some foot cream and you're golden. My husband called my feet \\"hippy feet\\" and wondered out loud if I could walk on coals. My children were getting cut by the sharp cracks on my toes when we were playing. INNOCENT CHILDREN WERE BEING HURT BY MY FEET!!! I figured it was time to do something. I had scheduled a pedicure, but the look of horror that I envisioned myself getting from the pedicurist made me want to do a pre-pedicure pedicure.<br /><br />My Microplane Colossal Pedicutre Rasp came in the mail this afternoon. I was giddy. I patiently waited for the kids to go to bed and got to work. At one point, they awoke, and asked me what I was doing. I thought about it, and then decided not to sugar coat it. I told them I was getting the dead skin off my feet. The look of disgust on their faces was priceless, as they stared at the impressive pile of powdered dead skin on the paper towels beneath me as I sat on my porcelain throne. \\"Get back to bed\\" I shouted. No one needs to see this. Eventually, they fell asleep. I'm not sure how, as this thing sounds like a hacksaw grinding away at my heels. Honestly, that's probably not too far from the truth. There was no pain. If it wasn't for the huge pile of foot dust below me, I might have doubted it was doing anything. But, with cracks the depth of the Grand Canyon, I probably had an inch to go through before I would get to anything with any feeling. I had read reviews about the ones who \\"went too far\\" on their first day with this thing, and I was wise enough to stop before too long. So far, I'm impressed! My feet actually look human again. I lathered them up with some foot cream (the one bottle that I had kept, \\"just incase\\") and I will be trying this again tomorrow, as long as I can walk in the morning.

  555. Okay, so I go barefoot unless society dictates that I must wear shoes. When I was younger, I took great pride in having &#34;feet as hard as horn&#34; (like Mowgli). I could care less what my feet look like, but they also HURT. So I bought this expecting a long, slow foot restoration process. Nope. After 35 years of resolute foot negligence, one session of light abrading with this device left my feet smooth and pink -- but not raw. Afterwards, I slathered some lotion on them, put on socks (blech) for the night, and woke to decent feet (they'll never be pretty) in the morning. In short, go carefully with this surprisingly powerful &#34;foot grater,&#34; and you'll be pleased with the results.

I grabbed the trash can, propped my foot over it, and started grating away.<br /><br />Oh my goodness, this pedicutre has literally changed my life. First of all, there is literally no pain. No more rough feet! No more bloody cracks in your heels!<br /><br />Be careful though since being too enthusiastic will yield soreness or even pain after you stop filing. Don't get carried away.   661. I bought it after having a nail technician use one on my feet during a pedicure. It was a couple extra bucks for a callous removal treatment that left my feet smoother than they've ever been. I was both grossed out and intrigued by watching the dead skin being grated off my feet like cheese (sorry) so I looked up microplanes on line and found this!<br /><br />Some background: I used to pick the skin on my feet compulsively out of stress and I also plated a competitive sport that left my feet very calloused. So I would pick my feet raw, and they would callous quickly again due to the physical activity, and then I would pick them and the cycle continued. As a result, the skin on my feet over-generates cells and I get thick, tough, dry and often itchy callouses on my feet. This naturally makes me want to pick at my feet even more.<br /><br />This is the ONLY product, and I've tried a lot of pumice stones/nail files/foot creams and masks, that successfully breaks through my super-tough fast-forming callouses. I always moisturizes right afterwards, and this leaves me with skin so soft and smooth that I don't feel the need to pick at all! Because my callouses are fast-forming, I have to use this once or twice a week to prevent myself from picking at my feet, but the results may be longer lasting for less active people.<br /><br />The only real problems I've had with this are accidentally nicking the tender skin on my ankles. You're supposed to use this on dry skin, and only on tough callouses--if you ever reach skin that starts to hurt when you're filing it, you've filed too much--so in my filing craze I have sometimes accidentally scraped my ankle and made a tiny cut. Nothing painful or bloody, but it is something to be careful about. The other issue is that sometimes it's hard to get a good angle on tough toe callouses given the size and shape of this microplane. I have never been able to fully file the callouses that form underneath my big toe, due to the curve of my toe (I have to use a regular nail file for this).<br /><br />If you have tender feet or not very thick callouses, I don't recommend this, because it could be easy to go overboard. Your feet carry a lot of weight so having a little bit of callous is important! Also be very careful not to use this on any areas with open cuts or broken or raw skin. It can tear at the skin easily. Use a nail file around those areas to be safe.<br /><br />Again, be sure to only use on dry and tough callouses, be careful about filing down too much, and moisturize right away and everything should be good!
  662. I've tried countless products to soften my feet and get rid of the calluses on my heels and toes. I followed the instructions, was careful while using it.   757. This works well, but there is an equivalent on Amazon that works even better -- in kitchenware, the Microplane grater 40020.<br /><br />There are two reasons why it is better -- first, the kiitchen device is sharper (at least, mine is) and sharper tools require less effort and are easier to control; second, the Microplane kitchen device works on the pull stroke rather than the push stroke that the pedicure rasp uses. This is important -- on the pull stroke it keeps the rasp attached to the skin and is more controllable than in push mode. That's why Japanese hand saws cut much more precisely with more control with the pull stroke than western saws that cut on the push stroke.<br /><br />So, for a few dollars more, get the better device from kitchenware.<br /><br />EDIT: After further use, I can see that the rasp is designed to work on the pull stroke as well as the push stroke because the \\"teeth\\" are set up with half facing each direction. However, I still say that the kitchen version works better, and maybe that is because all of the teeth work in the pull direction and the pull direction is the most useful.
  758. This rasp is great for in between nail salon visits. I would most certainly recommend this product to anyone with a interest in it.
  759. I use this regularly for heavy heel callouses then use Callous Blaster the 2 are all I need to keep my sandal feet in shape. Cheaper to get a pedicure without buying extra &#34;add ons&#34;. Be careful to be gentle and uses this lightly in stages so you won't go to deep & get sore spots wear callouses used to be.
  760. I have horrible dry feet. 'Nuff said. I have spent a fortune on them trying to remove dead skin, cracks, callouses and the such. This thing WORKS!!!   766. What a terrific application of the microplane technology.<br /><br />I'm not particularly concerned that the soles of my feet are attractive, but I've been mildly concerned for many years that the calluses on the back of my heels have had various superficial cracks running through their top layers. While they were never painful, they were rough, and I was mildly concerned that at some point they might deepen and somehow pose an infection risk.<br /><br />For a while I occasionally would try to file them down with fine sandpaper, which was so slow at removing skin that I never did enough of it to solve the problem.<br /><br />The microplane makes quick work of the problem, though. Mindful of the warnings of other commenters, I only did a few \\"passes\\" over each area per session. Yet significant improvement was there from the very first use.<br /><br />I'm waiting a few days between each usage, as I want to retain most of the toughness of the skin on my heel. Yet I can tell that it won't be long at all before the cracks have been planed off, leaving unbroken (yet still adequately tough) skin to protect my heels.<br /><br />Wow, this review makes me sound utterly OCD. In any event, I hope it helps someone.<br /><br />But buy this thing -- it's utterly effective, and fast and easy (and quite fun) to use.<br /><br />You won't regret this purchase.

  785. I am 40. I am male. I trim my toenails when they punch through my socks or my wife complains that I'm shredding the sheets. I have never removed a callus. I didn't even know what calluses were until mine got to the point that I could hardly walk from the pain of having quarter inch stalagmites of dead skin driving into my feet. I lost a bet with my wife and had to go get a pedicure, which was a total waste of 50 bucks getting a slimy foot rub from a high school dropout that looked like she was going to barf. So after that little gem of an experience I shopped around a bit and bought this bad boy, as per the Tribe of Amazon's reviews. In Amazon we trust.<br /><br />First of all let's get the griping over with: this should be jet black with a skull-and-crossbones, not chocolate brown. Power tools should all be black. A death motif is always a plus. This sucker should come with hardware for mounting it in your garage, or better yet a black holster you can strap to your leg. Because it's far more dangerous than any pistol. Han Solo could outshoot Greedo with this thing.<br /><br />Like all men, I tossed the instructions in the trash, whipped off my socks, and started filing away. The first thing I noticed was that a) it didn't hurt, and b) I was grinding off an unbelievable amount of dead skin. Because it didn't hurt I decided it was defective and started furiously sawing back and forth. Grind, grind, grind, and now skin was flying like dust from a bandsaw. That was more like it. After about 30 minutes on each foot I had the kind of beautiful, pink baby feet that fetishists dream about. Chucked the meat dust into the garbage, took a shower, and thought nothing of it as I went to bed.<br /><br />I'm pretty sure the next morning I awoke to the shrill from the smoke alarm going off. Did you know your feet can spontaneously combust? My beautiful pink piggies looked like denuded Vienna sausages. My heels were blood red and inflamed. I could hardly make it to the first aid kit. I wound up slathering about a gallon of Vaseline on each, wishing I had BP around to dump an oil spill on me. Through sheer manly perseverance (read: screaming profanity and crying like a wee girl) I was able to get socks and shoes on, despite my wife's humiliating laughter. I spent two crippling days hobbled to my desk at work and trying to walk as little as possible. Mornings and evenings meant more Vaseline and trips to the grocery store for econo vats of the stuff. By the way, standing in the express checkout with a pained expression while buying huge containers of Vaseline and a baguette your wife asked you to pick up is a great way to strike up a conversation with folks. Made some good friends, yes sir.<br /><br />TL;DR: this thing works. It's like a chainsaw for your feet. Just shave a little off at a time, and do it over the course of a few nights and not one sitting.t. I wound up slathering about a gallon of Vaseline on each, wishing I had BP around to dump an oil spill on me. I mean zero, it's pretty amazing actually considering I used to get pretty self-conscious having my shoes off near people. But, take it easy and take off 1/3 of what you would probably otherwise think is acceptable for removal or you may come across a lot of pain from digging to deep into your layers of flesh. It is very easy to get carried away with this thing and run it across your feet at warp speed, but it will take a few sessions regardless to get it to a level that's acceptable because no matter how much you file down the layers to get them soft, in 3 days your feet will develop another thick layer from the skin hardening to protect the feet which will require more work. All of the tools you will need, excluding a brain, can be found on Amazon. Now here's how you get the super soft, smooth feet you're dreaming of- Once a week before going to bed- shower (or just soak & clean your feet) & and once your skin has FULLY DRIED, use this Microplane foot file- DO NOT OVER DO IT! Then you're going to use a foot file with 2 sides (that looks like a giant emoryboard), start with the more coarse side & finish with the less coarse side. Use those arm muscles in this step! Then liberally slather on a thick ointment or cream (Vaseline or Cetaphil). Cover your feet with 2 pairs of COTTON socks, & sleep in them overnight. The rest of the week each night clean, mousturize, & cotton socks on the feet. I wash all the socks I use in this process with my towels in HOT WATER with bleach. Now I know what some of you are thinking- AIN'T NOBODY GOT TIME FOR THAT! Well, you better work it if you want the results.

  1093. I've used various soaks, lotions, creams, sloughing gels, special socks, pumice stones and rasps. (All a waste of time and money.) I even used the Microplane fine grater (from the kitchen/cooking utensils department). Hands down this one is best. (A close second is the kitchen grater with the same brand name, but for the same price this is much better.) The &#34;blade&#34; looks similar to the kitchen fine grater, but is different. It is specifically designed for peducure use. Big difference. Use it carefully. Follow the instructions. Use on dry skin. It is easy to go too far and draw blood. Do not apply pressure. Stop before you think you should. You can always do a little more in a couple days. You need to moisturize heavily afterward, because the exposed skin will be tender and needs to be kept moist or it will crack. I use cocoa butter. Baby soft feet, no more painful cracks or snagged hosiery, and I can throw away all that other stuff cluttering up the bathroom.

  1124. TL;DR Version: Buy this.<br /><br />I have had severe dry, hard skin on my heels for years. I have tried everything from soaks to PedEggs, and nothing put a dent in it.<br />Then I ordered this as a last resort. The reviews were overwhelmingly positive, and for eight bucks and change, what did I have to lose?<br />Turns out, this could have saved me hundreds of dollars in wasted products. Going by the insert and sawing in an up/down motion, the callused skin just came right off. I read several reviews that recommended doing a little at a time, and not trying to remove all the skin at once, but the results were still immediate- my heels felt softer and smoother. I'm on day two, and it feels like I got a pedicure.<br />A few tips:<br />1. This is completely painless, which makes it tempting to just saw on down to the new skin in one session. However, the new skin hasn't been exposed to sensation, so do this over a period of a few days and save yourself a lot of pain.<br />2. Do NOT use on wet skin. Using other pedicure rasps/eggs/razors, wet skin has always been easier to peel, but this thing is sharp and doesn't need the lubrication. It would wreck your feet.<br />3. Do this over a towel. The skin comes off as powder, and it makes an impossible mess on floors.

My feet are smoother after using this, so I'm not at all disappointed with the tool's performance, but I might prefer a tool designed for use on wet skin (softened callouses).

  1340. I'm a guy prone to getting bad calluses on my feet. I like to wear work boots with solid leather foot beds in them, so when my calluses get bad they really hurt. I tried shaving them with various devices, cutting them with clippers and sanding them, usually ending up with rough uneven patches of skin and leg and neck cramps. My wife suggested looking for something like this. I was a bit skeptical, but decided to try it because of all the raving reviews. Well, the reviews are right, this thing rocks! I don't even have to see what I'm doing. I just prop a foot up on something and put a trash can underneath and file away. This thing cuts clean and fast. It blends the callus area in nicely with the skin around it. I just gage the amount I need to file by poking the area with my finger nails until it's about even with the surrounding skin. This is one of those great little items that really helps out and I wish I would have discovered it long ago.

Speaking of, my own feet aren't that bad, or as bad as they've been in the past, but the heel was still a bit tough and dry and would get itchy without lotion. I used the plane by running it in different directions over my heel, meaning multi-directional swipes. I believe that kept my foot from getting that rough, raspy feel. If I felt a spot that was raspy after I had worked on it I would try running the plane in a different direction, which seemed to smooth it. And at no time did I put much pressure on the device! Don't gouge your foot, just lightly run it over with the pressure of your fingers. My heels came away from the treatment smooth. And as another reviewer posted, do it several times a week lightly rather than risk creating sore spots by going too far. I would definitely buy this tool again if need be, and glad I took a chance on it.

You should do it over a trash can, newspaper or outside to catch the dry skin, which comes off as a fine powder.<br /><br />Be careful when using this thing. The blades are sharper than you realize until you accidentally nick yourself on soft skin, such as your ankle like I did. Also, I think I was a little too aggressive the first time I used it, so my feet were a bit tender the next day. The review that spoke about this issue is correct -- you don't really realize you are doing too much until the next day. At the time, it feels fine. Just go slow and remove the worst of it, and if you want to try removing more in the next few days, maybe try it again then.

I seem to have a genetic predisposition to growing callouses that could set world records combined with limited mobility in my right leg from breaking my hip as a kid - which means I have nasty feet that are hard to reach. Over the years I have tried this and tried that and some things work not at all and some things work a little bit but nothing really lasts if you don't really, really keep on top of it - and getting back to that limited mobility thing, I don't keep on top of it. (I can reach my left foot easily, but have to twist my right foot behind my body to work on it, and it's annoying). I've tried filing wet (the tweezerman pedra file is pretty good in the shower) and I've tried filing dry (heavy black nail files things) but everything, at best, has made my feet look normal but I still have that crazy thick patch of callous ready to look horrible at any moment.<br /><br />This file revealed skin I haven't seen since I was 8 years old. Honestly. I think it's been lurking under there and the other stuff just keeps growing on top of it.<br /><br />It took off so much callous, and so thoroughly, that my feet stayed looking and feeling NORMAL for at least two weeks, when I got around to using it again.<br /><br />Seriously amazed.<br /><br />The only down side is it is HUGE which makes it great for heals but not smaller areas, so I am sticking with black files for the rest of my feet. I especially recommend it for any man embarrassed to stroll into a nail shop and get his soles re-done.
  1775. I tried it based on reviews; and after just one time, threw away my pedi-egg that never did as good a job. You do need to be a bit careful - don't use it vigorously - it is much more effective than any other product of this kind that I have tried so don't do it too hard.
